steps.text: Welcome to our video on Women in Science during the 20th Century, where we'll explore the incredible contributions and challenges faced by pioneering women scientists.
During this century, many women broke barriers and paved the way for future generations, defying societal norms and making groundbreaking discoveries.
One famous figure is Marie Curie, a physicist and chemist who conducted pioneering research on radioactivity. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize.
Despite her achievements, Curie faced significant gender-based discrimination but prevailed with her scientific pursuits, leading to two Nobel Prizes in different sciences.
Another notable scientist is Rosalind Franklin, whose work with X-ray diffraction images of DNA was critical to understanding its double-helix structure.
Unfortunately, Franklin did not receive the recognition she deserved during her lifetime, but her contributions remain vital to genetics.
We also look at Chien-Shiung Wu, a Chinese-American experimental physicist who made significant contributions to nuclear physics.
Wu is best known for the Wu experiment, which disproved the law of conservation of parity, changing the global understanding of physics.
Despite being pivotal in her field, Wu faced the dual challenge of being a woman and an Asian scientist in a predominantly white, male domain.
Through determination and brilliance, these women and many others have inspired future generations of female scientists, pushing the boundaries of what is possible.

full_story:
In this video, we will delve into the remarkable stories of pioneering women in science during the 20th century. This era was marked by significant scientific advancements, many of which were contributed by women who challenged societal norms and broke through glass ceilings to make their mark on the scientific world. 

Marie Curie, a Polish-born physicist and chemist, stands out among these trailblazers. Curie conducted groundbreaking research in radioactivity—a term she coined. Despite facing considerable biases, she became the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and she remains the only woman to win in multiple sciences, cementing her legacy as a trailblazer in her field. 

Another monumental figure is Rosalind Franklin, whose extensive work with X-ray diffraction led to the understanding of the DNA double-helix structure. While her contributions were crucial, she faced significant recognition challenges, partly due to her gender and her untimely death. 

Chien-Shiung Wu, a Chinese-American physicist, made pivotal contributions to the field of nuclear physics. Her experiments revolutionized the understanding of particle physics, particularly through her work that demonstrated the violation of the conservation of parity. Although her contributions were essential, Wu contended with the complexities of identity in the sciences, both as a woman and as a Chinese immigrant. 

These women, among others, have inspired generations, proving that talent and perseverance can lead to groundbreaking achievements regardless of the barriers one faces.
